title: 112_hr6030
content: The "Hire Now Act of 2012" may be cited as the short title. It includes a temporary tax credit for increased payroll. The "Hire Now Act of 2012" offers a temporary tax credit for qualified employers equal to 10% of the excess wages and compensation paid in 2012 compared to 2011, with a maximum credit of $5,000,000. Wages are defined as per section 3121 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The term "compensation" is defined under section 3231 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for tax purposes. The contribution and benefit base for 2011 is determined by the Social Security Act for wages and compensation. For qualified employers with zero wages and compensation in 2011, 80% of the amount under subsection (a)(1) is considered. The excess amount under subsection (a) is reduced by all other Federal tax credits related to wages in 2012. The term "qualified employer" is defined under section 3111(d)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The term "qualified services" refers to services performed by an individual not described in the Higher Education Act of 1965. Aggregation rules from the Internal Revenue Code apply to determine when multiple entities are considered a single employer. Predecessor and successor employer rules may also be applied as prescribed by the Secretary of the Treasury. The term "qualified services" refers to services performed by an individual not described in the Higher Education Act of 1965. Rules similar to sections 280C(a) and 6501(m) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 apply to the credit determined under this section. The credit allowed under subsection (a) for qualified services shall be added to the current year business credit under section 38(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for taxable employers. Unused business credit cannot be carried back before the enactment of this section. The credit allowed under subsection (a) for qualified services will be treated as a credit under subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code. Additionally, it will be added to the credits described in section 6211(b)(4) of the Code. Section 1324(b)(2) of title 31, United States Code, will be amended to include credits due under the Hire Now Act of 2012. The Secretary will pay possessions of the United States with mirror code tax systems amounts equal to their losses due to specified subsections. For possessions without mirror code tax systems, the Secretary will estimate the amounts to be paid. The Secretary will pay possessions of the United States with mirror code tax systems amounts equal to their losses due to specified subsections. For possessions without mirror code tax systems, the Secretary will estimate the amounts to be paid based on implementing an income tax benefit equivalent to the income tax credit allowed under such subsections. No increase in the credit against US income taxes for any taxable year due to specific reasons shall be considered for individuals eligible for a credit or payment under certain tax provisions. The term "possession of the United States" includes various territories. The term "mirror code tax system" refers to the income tax system of any possession of the United States where residents' tax liability is determined by referencing US income tax laws. Payments under this subsection are treated similarly to refunds under credit provisions. The Secretary will prescribe regulations to implement the provisions of this section regarding refunds and credit provisions. Prohibition on using last-in, first-out accounting for major integrated oil companies. The amendment prohibits major integrated oil companies from using the last-in, first-out accounting method for inventorying goods, effective for taxable years after the enactment of the Act. Taxpayers affected by this change must initiate the method accounting change for their first taxable year after the Act's enactment. The taxpayer must initiate a change in accounting method with the consent of the Secretary of the Treasury. The adjustments required under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will be spread out over a period of up to 8 taxable years. The amendment limits the deduction for intangible drilling and development costs of major integrated oil companies. It applies to amounts paid or incurred in taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act.
